column1: Additional Medication to Treat Partial Seizures

column9: I have only been on Zonegran for a few weeks. I take 200mg at night. So far it has worked better than Tegretol & Keppra. I have no seizure since being on any of the meds, but the side affects of Keppra was not good. I slept in, gained weight, stayed up late. Not real interested in anything. So the Dr. switched me to Tegretol, even thou I begged to to be on Zonegran. He denied me & put me on Tegretol, & once I started taking that pill, all worse side affects happened. I gained a lot of weight the first week. Could not go to the bath room, even taking meds that was suppose to help clean the system. I was really angry. My depression self esteem hit rock bottom, & I just felt like I was on a path of life not looking good. So now here I am, Zonegran. So far so good. Thanks to reviews, & studying seizure meds, it has opened doors for me to understand what are my options.

column2: 45-54 (Patient)
column9: Started taking this medication in lieu of lyrica....what a blessing! I not only lost the weight gained from the lyrica, but all the heaviness of the joints and the pain has disappeared. column2: joyous4376, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: kjfred, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: marlasgone, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have temporal lobe epilepsy which I had surgery to correct on 7/25/10.  For several years I had intractible seizures, and my body just plain didn't seem to like anti-convulsants.  I suffered with side effects, some life threatening (literally), until this was introduced.  I must admit, even since the surgery I have had quite a few strong auras (I get complex partial seizures) but absolutely NO side effects.  And in 8 months of being on this medication, I've only had my dosage increased once for seizure activity.  That's incredible for me.  It usually gets increased monthly.  I will be taking this until I'm finally able to be weaned off of anti-convulsants altogether (here's hoping...:-)

column2: cebellezza, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I am now on my second round of taking Zonegran for Bipolar Disorder.  First time maxed out at 600mg- worked GREAT but I lost too much weight after 18 months.  Now, after app. 18 months, weight is being maintained with other meds.  Great med for my mood stabilization (for the most part)!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

But for the most part, my migraines are somewhat under control.

column1: Additional Medication to Treat Partial Seizures

column9: This is my 3rd anti-convulsant in the past 12 months.  My body doesn't tend to respond well to them.  This is the ONLY one with which I haven't experienced negative side effects!  I had brain surgery 2 months ago during which the source of my seizures was removed and am still taking the same dose.  I have had 1 seizure since being on Zonegran which, ironically, was after my surgery, but I had missed a dose the prior evening.  Overall this drug is a Godsend compared to the other anti-convulsants I've had (Lamictal, Trileptal.)

column2: Journey, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

Does anyone else have the same problems with time?

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I started having seizures almost five years ago. First they put me on Keppra, which was a disaster. Then they switched me to Topamax, which was okay but didn't completely stop the seizures. Then I was on Lamictal, which was actually working for a while, but then I had two series of break-through seizures. Last year, I was put on Zonegran, and haven't had a single seizure. I just tend to be exhausted more frequently and eat a lot less.

column2: cboo_kitties, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)

I still have issues with some memory, not being able to find the right words to say when having a conversation, and occasionally my motor skills are off but in the big scheme of things, if my seizures are under control I am very happy and can deal with it.

After the 5th time in the hospital it was finally determined my body had built some type of immunity to the drug causing me to develop the kidney stones.  *off to the next drug*

column2: lackej1971, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I took this Rx for about 6 months. It was pure hell. My doctor had me taking Depakote AND Zonisamide at the same time. I could feel my brain as if it were "boiling" in my skull. EXTREME paranoia and hallucinations. Terrible side effects on my liver and kidney function that I still suffer today. My memory was COMPLETELY gone. I could not even finish a sentence. I have never felt more out of control of myself than when I was on this drug. I was on an emotional roller coaster so severe that I was suicidal. FINALLY, in desperation, I begged my doctor to just put me back on Depakote. It has it's share of side effects too, but at least I don't feel like punching my ticket and checking out. Zonisamide is a VERY dangerous drug. The only good side to it is that I was so hyperactive and not the least bit hungry, that I lost quite a bit of weight. I've since gained it all right back since I quit though. Take it if you must, but if you have ANY of these signs, talk to your doctor IMMEDIATELY!!!

column2: beestill, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This medication was prescribed for Migraine treatment . The two years I was taking it was a holy hell. I immediately began losing muscular strength  and had tremors in my arms and legs. At 41 and very healthy that was weird. My memory and cognitive abilities dropped like a stone.( I was  PHD in Math)They tested me for things like MS etc, and psych tests. Finally I got a good neurologist and after a month off of the drug I was  thinking and spelling and reading, doing complex math at my pre zonegran state, without tremors etc.I'd rather have a migraine then lose my brain- this drug should be off the market.

column2: gina, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have Fibro and have been perscribed Lyrica,Neurontin and now Zonegran. column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I took this drug for MANY years as migraine prevention.  I started at 100mg when that was the only one available and slowly lowered my dosage until I finally was able to go off it.  It worked wonders, I went from having 2-4 migraines a week to 1 a month and then none at all.  I have stopped the zonegran for a few months now and I have not suffered a migraine!

column2: sunshine, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed Zonegran for severe migraines.We had tried Topamax but I had several side effects to that medication. It took a while for us to regulate the amount of zonegran needed.I was taking 400-500 mgs daily. I lost 40 lbs, was nauseated, had difficulty concentrating.It was worth it to have control over the dibilitating migraines.My quality of life improved. After taking this medication for 3 years, I stopped it on my own, thinking I could get by without it. (I had a hysterectomy and the headaches were less frequent.) I was sick of seeing doctors. This was a mistake. I now regret my decision.Gained the 40 lbs back.Would have liked to have kept the 40 lbs off.  I can concentrate better and do not feel like I am in a "fog". However, I also feel the migraines returning and feel the shocking sensation shoot across my brain prior to a migraine. If zonegran works for you...do not discontinue it. I'm sorry I did.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I like this medication because I can take it all at one time rather than taking it in the morning and at night.  It's easier for me to remember.  It helps both with the seizures and with my Migraines.  I can live with the side effects as I had most of the same side effects on Topamax.

column2: Carpeteater, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Serious kidney and liver problems have guided my specialist to now instruct me to withdraw from this drug

column2: Melissa, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I think meds work differnt for everyone.  I was on Trileptal for 2 years.  I gained 50 lbs and I was still have seizures.  My doc finally changed me to Zonegran and I think it is a miracle drug. I lost the 50 lbs I gained and nest of all...  I have been seizure free for almost 7 years.  He told me I could go off of it if I wanted to but I am too afraid that I will have one while driving and I don't want to take that chance!

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: My seizures began immediately after an auto accident in Oct of 2002.  I was first placed on Neurontin what further debilitated me and I even had grand mal on this drug.  Lamictal caused Stevens-Johnsons syndrome.  Keppra put me in a coma.  Tegratol reduced my seizures and along with the addition of a seizure alert dog gave me some independence.  After adding Zonegran, my seizures ceased.  Beware of generic though, they contain lactose as an inert ingredient that is not generally made known to doctors and pharmacists.  I am severly lactose intolerate and got very sick before we discovered the lactose hidden in the 4 100mg generic Zonegran I was taking daily.  As soon as we switched to brand name and make sure it is always brand name ordered by doctor and approved by insurance I have been great since 2006.

column2: OBWON56, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)

column2: sunset, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This is the best Epileptic Drug to control the Complex Partial, Simple Partial, Electrographic, and Absence seizures. Absolutely no side effect at all. It is the main antiepileptic drug which normally is considered to be an adjunctive drug. As intractable (or refractory) as I am; having been on this drug now for nearly 3 years without any side effects at all - been doing one heck of a job when all the other antiepileptic drugs could not do or last due to allergic reactions or severe side effects. It is working great alongside with Klonopin (Clonazepam). I strongly recommend the brand name Zonegran over Zonisamide due to formulary differences.

column9: Have still had partial complex seizures on this medication. Has not helped a lot had to take many pills at a time.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I loved this medication. I'm a student in college and it allowed me to live my life. I had one or two mild break through seisures and that was about it. It allowed me to think and do everything I wanted to do.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have lupus and started having convulsive, and partial focal siezures. I started on dilantin then went to dilantin with lamictal and now I'm on zonegran with lamictal and this has been going on since 1999. I didn't have any real side effects with the first treatments until I went onto the zonegran and now I seem to have the works memory loss, extremly tired, mood swing very angry mood swings,loss of interest in my children,  nausea, stomache pain. They all started when within a couple months of starting this medication and my Doctor never told me that these could be possible side effect and now that I've been on it and there isn't really any thing  else left for me they just want me to deal with them. I ever have gone to the gastro doctor who has given me 4 differnt meds for the stomache pain even though they don't know whats wrong. Not to mention the fact that I yell at my kids and then go cry because I shouldn't have. If I had know the risks I wouldn't have taken this medication because I don't think its doing a good enough job. the doctor didn't either I now have a vagus nerve stimulator but have to take the meds till it works.

column2: metomic, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years
column9: My doctor prescribed this to help with neuropathic pain in my feet after I suffered chronic inflammatory demylinating polyradiculoneuropathy and was paralyzed and intubated for 5 months in the hospital. This was after trying several other meds.  The combination of this and nortriptylene has helped this nerve pain.

column2: plb@health.state.ny.us, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: This drug is prescribed to me for neuropathy.  As an RN, I am wondering why more people aren't using it as it is bid instead of the tid to qid dosing of neurontin, etc.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been presribed this medication for cronic pain, it has allowed me to cut down on narcotic pain meds like oxycotin

column9: Need to make capsules in larger dosages.  Taking 8 capsules at night is hard.

column9: This drug was perscribed to me for a purpose of nothing to do w/seizures.  it was perscribed for helping me with mantal clarity and ability to be able to stay focused in thinking while going through depression from divorce - it worked great
